title: Overview

content:
Some wise person said “Marry the right person, this one decision will have the most long lasting impact on your life and your happiness” (maybe it was a song). I met Michelle in the second year of my Masters Degree at the faculty Christmas party. Her steak was rare and my steak had the consistency of a shoe… we switched steaks. We got engaged on valentines day and were married in August. Our son Justin was born the following March (at the end of March!). Our second son, David, turned one the year we moved to Edmonton.
Michelle is the yin to my yang - she has been involved in the not-for-profit sector for most of her career, I have been working for a hockey team (with no socially redeeming qualities). She is presently the Chair of the Edmonton Public School Board (I am a-political and was terrified my first time door-knocking with her). In addition to her Masters Degree in Leisure Studies (University of Ottawa) she holds a Master Of Science Degree (Human Ecology, University of Alberta), a teaching degree (Concordia College) and she is presently enrolled in a PhD program at the University of Western Ontario (Educational Leadership) - I left school before completing my PhD and have never looked back.
Career and Academics aside, she holds the professional designation of Certified Professional Evaluator - and this is where the fun begins.
Michelle has run her own Program Evaluation consulting business quite successfully for the last few years. Evaluators are in high demand - and are almost as sexy as data scientists. Whenever she had a “data problem” or needed a t-test done, I would get the call. As more and more projects piled up, she turned to me for help. I am not an evaluator, and program evaluation is still a bit like C++ to me - its a tough language to learn and their are rules but you can do a lot with it if you put in the work. A funny thing happened to me while working for the Oilers - I learned to type almost as fast as I could think. In meetings, I would transcribe live notes to the screen as we discussed players, trades, draft picks. Seeing these discussions appear live in real time on the screen was helpful to mangement and scouts. It turns out, my scouting staff meetings were just focus groups, and Michelle ran focus groups all the time. Michelle likes flip charts and post-it-notes, and they have served her well in her career. After much convincing I finally got her to agree to letting me “mind map” one of her focus groups (this was in addition to her post-it-notes, because, change is hard!). I like MindNode, but have been doing work in coggle.it lately because it is platform independent and shares better. She still likes her post-it-notes, but had to agree that live mind mapping was an awesome way to run a focus group.
Helping Michelle with some of her projects gave me a great deal of personal and professional satisfaction. Personal in that the projects she was working on were, for the most part, not-for-profit organizations looking to make a difference in the world - something I had never been a part of. Professional in that the people in those organizations recognized the value of the evidence we were providing (ours was an evidence-based decision making approach) and they were happy to listen to our recommendations and put them to use. When the Oilers decided not to renew my contract, I was ready to ease into the world of consulting. I am a technology specialist first and foremost, so that is what I focused on. I now work with not-for-profit organizations. I help get them away from expensive software and database platforms. Microsoft and Google both offer no-cost not-for-profit pricing, and both platforms come with their own data management capabilities. Google Sheets or SharePoint can replace a propitiatory database service. The really enjoyable part is building capacity in-house with these organizations, helping them to take ownership of their own data and then helping them build out their reporting. And they listen to me when I make a suggestion and I never hear “my gut says otherwise” or “I don’t trust the data.”
The more work you do around program evaluation, the more you start to pick up things. In building a data management platform for a client, we started looking at their program indicators first, and then built the system to capture those indicators. Different funders had different indicators they needed reporting on - parameterized reports in R Markdown fit quite well. In program evaluation there is this thing called the Theory of Change. Its an if…then statement but you don’t have to be a programmer to understand it. It goes something like this:
Theory of Change If [we do the things we have said we should do]… then [we will see this long term result with the people we are working with]
A theory of change is a foundational statement that provides an understanding of the pathway to change. It clarifies expectations among diverse stakeholders and highlights common understanding regarding intended outcomes of the proposed change. - and please don’t try to wordsmith it after it has been approved! Everyone in the organization is supposed to buy into this statement, and it serves as a reference point for the evaluation.
 Logic Model The next step is the logic model and it is here that things really start to get interesting from a data science perspective. According to Michelle, a logic model is “a visual illustration of a program’s inputs (or resources), activities, outputs and expected outcomes. It is a tool used to describe relationships between various components” An Organization’s Theory of Change and Logic Model is what puts them in position to ask the right questions to lead to the evaluation of their program. At this years rstudio::conf (Austin TX.) I met many people who talked about being involved in Program Evaluation, but as I got deeper in discussions with them, logic models and theory of change did not play much of a role, if any. Most of the time they were brought in to deal with the data, and often had to tell their clients:
 “You can not answer the question you want with the data you have collected”
 So where do you go from there, and how do you avoid this situation?
summary: Some wise person said “Marry the right person, this one decision will have the most long lasting impact on your life and your happiness” (maybe it was a song). I met Michelle in the second year of my Masters Degree at the faculty Christmas party. Her steak was rare and my steak had the consistency of a shoe… we switched steaks. We got engaged on valentines day and were married in August.
title: Data Science Meets Program Evaluation

content:
In the end it came as no surprise to me. The Oilers wanted to go in a different direction, and so did I. Twenty years is a long time to be in the same role in the same organization. When Glen Sather hired me away from the National Hockey League Players’ Association in 1998 he gave me the title “Director of Research, Analysis and Software Development” - and that’s pretty much what I did. If ever there was a career path destined to lead into Data Scientist this was it. I started down this path at the University of Ottawa where I had completed my Masters Degree in Sports Psychology and was on my way to a PhD in Psycho-pedagogy when I realized I had stopped caring about the topic of my dissertation (A comparison of the structure of knowledge of ice hockey coaches to symphony orchestra composers). I had been hired as a sessional instructor to teach research methods and statistics classes and I found teaching vastly more stimulating than my PhD. I was good at it. Students were transferring into my classes from other departments, and I was given more classes to teach. I taught probability, hypothesis testing, regression and correlation in SPSS 7.0.
Looking back, it was the technology and the data that fueled my passion. While other students saw research methods and statistics as a terrifying and confusing means to an end, I saw my career path. If I could excel at something that frightened so many of my peers I would be set for life. The fact that I loved what I was doing was a bonus. Driven by data and technology it was not long before I found my way into programming - I started app development Visual FoxPro and that was enough to get me hired by the Quebec Nordiques to help them build out their scouting system (OK, that and the fact my father was their Chief Scout at the time). FoxPro was like a gateway drug for me, and soon led to Visual Studio and SQL server. I was teaching myself so I decided Visual Basic was a better choice than any of the “C” languages. Then the iPhone came along and everyone wanted mobile apps so I left the Microsoft world and started to program for Apple devices, first in FileMaker, then in XCode.
People seem to think “Analytics” did not exist in sports until the movie “Moneyball” came out. I would disagree. We had been analyzing the draft and player performance (both on and off-ice) for as long as I was with the team. The movie and subsequent explosion of bloggers forced NHL teams to use the word “Analytics” when talking to the media to ensure their fans knew their team was on the cutting edge. Some teams had consultants, some had an “analytics guy” others held firm to their gut instinct. Ah, the gut instinct. Most people on the hockey side of management are former players, and math may not have been the option they picked in high school. You spend more time explaining fundimental concepts than you do communicating the findings of your research, and what little time left for your research is mostly spent dealing with “well, this one player I remember…” They were quick to jump to anecdotes to make their point, and even quicker to jump on the one player who proved to be the exception to the trend. The better scouts and management would try to understand and make use of the research, but many would ignore anything that went against their gut instincts and then pick the one thing that supported their position.
Along the way I connected to just about every database format in existence (and a few that are now extinct). Remember lotus notes? The NHL marketing department made a deal with IBM, so for years after Notes had faded into obscurity we were still using it to run the league. Notes must have been bad if scraping websites, parsing JSON, XML and building XSLT made me happy! By 2016 things were running smoothly. I had all the data I could want, I had all the platforms I thought I needed to build apps. Then I found R. R Studio sat on my computer for 6 months before I had the opportunity to really play with it. Knowing what was required to learn a new programming language, I really had to see the benefit before committing myself to the task. The NHLSCRAPEr package provided me all the motivation I needed. Very quickly R replaced most of my development platforms - it was easier to build tidy data outside FileMaker and then pull in my clean data to whatever app I had built. I was content, for a little while, until Shiny came along and made me abandon my application development.
The volume of data available in hockey has grown exponentially. Goals, assists, points, PIMs have now expanded to 3000+ “micro events” captured by complex pattern recognition algorithms. The amount of data extracted from a single hockey game has become unmanageable. I went to R Studio::conf 2018 and attended the Applied Machine Learning workshop to develop a plan to deal with all that data. I certainly came away with a lot more than Applied Machine Learning. I went in to my 20th and final NHL Entry Draft with the Edmonton Oilers armed with a Bayesian analysis of pre-draft player performance and a complete visual analysis of every player rating, assessment, skill set, all hosted on shinyapps.io.
After the draft the Oilers decided to go in another direction.
The company had “right-sized” a sicnificant portion their staff earlier in the season. I was at the dentist the morning security escorted people out of the building, but I heard about it quickly enough. I didn’t really know what to expect when I showed up that afternoon, but as it turned out, they did not make any changes in Hockey Operations. They saved those changes until after the draft - which makes sense because you probably don’t want to remove the guy who runs your draft until after the draft. In the end, they let the “coders” go - those of us who understood how to ask and answer questions with data and build tools to enable management to do the same, and kept a much smaller staff of “users” - those who could login to a website and download a report or Google something for management.
At this point in the story Data Science was about to run right into Program Evaluation.
summary: In the end it came as no surprise to me. The Oilers wanted to go in a different direction, and so did I. Twenty years is a long time to be in the same role in the same organization. When Glen Sather hired me away from the National Hockey League Players’ Association in 1998 he gave me the title “Director of Research, Analysis and Software Development” - and that’s pretty much what I did.

content: More detail can easily be written here using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: Person re-identification is a critical security task for recognizing a person across spatially disjoint sensors. Previous work can be computationally intensive and is mainly based on low-level cues extracted from RGB data and implemented on a PC for a fixed sensor network (such as traditional CCTV). We present a practical and efficient framework for mobile devices (such as smart phones and robots) where high-level semantic soft biometrics are extracted from RGB and depth data. By combining these cues, our approach attempts to provide robustness to noise, illumination, and minor variations in clothing. This mobile approach may be particularly useful for the identification of persons in areas ill-served by fixed sensors or for tasks where the sensor position and direction need to dynamically adapt to a target. Results on the BIWI dataset are preliminary but encouraging. Further evaluation and demonstration of the system will be available on our website.
title: A Person Re-Identification System For Mobile Devices

content: More detail can easily be written here using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: We present a mobile visual clothing search system whereby a smart phone user can either choose a social networking photo or take a new photo of a person wearing clothing of interest and search for similar clothing in a retail database. From the query image, the person is detected, clothing is segmented, and clothing features are extracted and quantized. The information is sent from the phone client to a server, where the feature vector of the query image is used to retrieve similar clothing products from online databases. The phone's GPS location is used to re-rank results by retail store location. State of the art work focuses primarily on the recognition of a diverse range of clothing offline and pays little attention to practical applications. Evaluated on a challenging dataset, the system is relatively fast and achieves promising results.
title: Mobile visual clothing search
